bibl.title: The Integration of the Eastern Desert Into the Islamic World: Beja Groups in Medieval Islamic Geography and Archaeological Records.
Navigated Spaces, Connected Places. Proceedings of Red Sea Project V Held at the University of Exeter, 16-19 September 2010.

bibl.note: Introduction. - Networking of Beja group leaders during the medieval period. - Benefits beyond the leader level: The integration of Beja individual families in trade networks. - Conclusion.
bibl.seg: Petra Weschenfelder, The Integration of the Eastern Desert Into the Islamic World: Beja Groups in Medieval Islamic Geography and Archaeological Records.

Dionisius A. Agius, John P. Cooper, Athena Trakadas & Chiara Zazzaro (edd.), Navigated Spaces, Connected Places. Proceedings of Red Sea Project V Held at the University of Exeter, 16-19 September 2010 = British Foundation for the Study of Arabia Monographs. 12 = BAR International Series. 2346 (Oxford, 2012) pp. 221-228.
Introduction. - Networking of Beja group leaders during the medieval period. - Benefits beyond the leader level: The integration of Beja individual families in trade networks. - Conclusion.
